questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman presents at 29 weeks gestation with headache and a blood pressure of 160/110 mm Hg. Investigations reveal 2+ proteinuria on dipstick, an elevated SGOT and SGPT and a platelet count of 80,000/mm 3 . What is the best management?

options.label: C
options.text: Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour

questions.correct_answer: C. Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1852, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1852, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 20-year primi presented at 32 weeks with eclampsia. She was started on MgSO4 (Pritchard’s regime) and she delivered after induction of labor. Maintenance dose of MgSO4 was continued for 24 hours. Prevention of Mg toxicity involves monitoring of the following clinical parameters:

options.label: A
options.text: Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

options.label: B
options.text: Deep tendon reflexes, O2 saturation, consciousness status

options.label: C
options.text: O2 saturation, urine output, heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: Heart rate, BP, respiratory rate and urine output

questions.correct_answer: A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The prevention of magnesium toxicity in the management of eclampsia involves careful monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate. Deep tendon reflexes help detect early signs of toxicity, urine output indicates renal function and magnesium clearance, and respiratory rate assesses potential respiratory depression from magnesium sulfate.
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition

questions.text: A 22-year Primigravida presents at 34 weeks to the emergency with a BP of 160/110 mmHg. Her urine albumin is 3 +. She is complaining of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, the fetal heart cannot be auscultated. The uterus is relaxed, and a vaginal examination reveals a soft cervix which is 1 cm dilated and 30% effaced. You administer IV labetalol to lower her BP. What is the best immediate next line of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Urgent Ultrasound to see the fetal status

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prophylactic MgSO4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Management of Preeclampsia: Definitive treatment is delivery Mild preeclampsia: Termination at 37 weeks Severe preeclampsia Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4 Start anti-hypertensives Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if Persistent severe HTN Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC Fetal compromise Abruption Pre-viable fetus Steroids (Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart IM) for lung maturity if < 34 weeks
  • ➤ Management of Preeclampsia:
  • ➤ Definitive treatment is delivery
  • ➤ Mild preeclampsia: Termination at 37 weeks
  • ➤ Severe preeclampsia Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4 Start anti-hypertensives Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if Persistent severe HTN Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC Fetal compromise Abruption Pre-viable fetus
  • ➤ Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4 Start anti-hypertensives Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if Persistent severe HTN Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC Fetal compromise Abruption Pre-viable fetus
  • ➤ Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4
  • ➤ Start anti-hypertensives
  • ➤ Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if Persistent severe HTN
  • ➤ Persistent severe HTN
  • ➤ Persistent severe HTN
  • ➤ Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC
  • ➤ Fetal compromise
  • ➤ Abruption
  • ➤ Pre-viable fetus
  • ➤ Steroids (Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart IM) for lung maturity if < 34 weeks
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 732, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 732, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Which is NOT an indication of using this drug in obstetrics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Severe IUGR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ MgSO4 is used for the following obstetric indications.
  • ➤ Eclampsia & severe preeclampsia As a tocolytic in preterm labor For neuroprotection in very preterm
  • ➤ Eclampsia & severe preeclampsia
  • ➤ As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  • ➤ For neuroprotection in very preterm
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition

questions.text: All are true regarding predictive tests for preeclampsia except?

options.label: A
options.text: An exaggerated diastolic notch is seen beyond 24 weeks on uterine artery Doppler in women at risk for developing pre-eclampsia.

options.label: B
options.text: A drop in levels of PAPP-A and PlGF is a predictor for preeclampsia.

options.label: C
options.text: Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are decreased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: Cell free DNA is increased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia due to accelerated apoptosis of cytotrophoblasts

questions.correct_answer: C. Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are decreased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are decreased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Predictors of preeclampsia:
  • ➤ Predictors of preeclampsia:
  • ➤ Biophysical markers : Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11 – 14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester). Biochemical markers:
  • ➤ Biophysical markers : Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11 – 14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester).
  • ➤ Biophysical markers
  • ➤ Biochemical markers:
  • ➤ Biochemical markers:
  • ➤ S-Flt-1 and s-Eng are Anti-angiogenic factors (Not angiogenic) Roll over test : 28- 32 weeks: BP is measured with patient on her side first and then she is asked to roll on her back and BP is checked again -an increase of 20mmHg in diastolic BP from lateral to supine position is a positive test – 30% of such women will develop pre-eclampsia in the future. This test is not done anymore. Angiotensin II sensitivity test : Rise in BP with Angiotensin II infusion.
  • ➤ S-Flt-1 and s-Eng are Anti-angiogenic factors (Not angiogenic)
  • ➤ Anti-angiogenic factors (Not angiogenic)
  • ➤ Roll over test : 28- 32 weeks: BP is measured with patient on her side first and then she is asked to roll on her back and BP is checked again -an increase of 20mmHg in diastolic BP from lateral to supine position is a positive test – 30% of such women will develop pre-eclampsia in the future. This test is not done anymore.
  • ➤ Roll over test
  • ➤ Angiotensin II sensitivity test : Rise in BP with Angiotensin II infusion.
  • ➤ Angiotensin II sensitivity test
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 35-year primigravida is worried about her risk of developing preeclampsia. What intervention would help reduce the risk in her?

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium supplementation started prior to 12 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Antioxidants – ascorbic acid and α-tocopherol prior to 12 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Low-dose aspirin started before 16 weeks of gestation is a recommended intervention to reduce the risk of developing preeclampsia, particularly for women at high risk.
  • ➤ Low-dose aspirin started before 16 weeks of gestation is a recommended intervention to reduce the risk of developing preeclampsia, particularly for women at high risk.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1825, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1825, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Anti-hypertensives contra-indicated in pregnancy are all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Alpha-methyldopa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The anti-hypertensive drug of choice in pregnancy is labetalol Alpha-methyldopa is considered safe and is one of the preferred anti hypertensives in pregnancy. However, ACE inhibitors (like captopril and enalapril) and ARBs (like losartan) are contraindicated due to their potential adverse effects on the developing fetus.
  • ➤ The anti-hypertensive drug of choice in pregnancy is labetalol
  • ➤ Alpha-methyldopa is considered safe and is one of the preferred anti hypertensives in pregnancy.
  • ➤ However, ACE inhibitors (like captopril and enalapril) and ARBs (like losartan) are contraindicated due to their potential adverse effects on the developing fetus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: All are regimes of MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Magpie regime

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The key educational takeaway is that while there are several recognized regimens for the administration of magnesium sulfate in the management of eclampsia (like the Dhaka, Sibai, and Zuspan regimens), the "Magpie regime" is not one of them. Instead, the Magpie Trial was a significant research study that helped establish the effectiveness of magnesium sulfate in this context.
  • ➤ The key educational takeaway is that while there are several recognized regimens for the administration of magnesium sulfate in the management of eclampsia (like the Dhaka, Sibai, and Zuspan regimens), the "Magpie regime" is not one of them.
  • ➤ Instead, the Magpie Trial was a significant research study that helped establish the effectiveness of magnesium sulfate in this context.
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks has a BP recording of 150/100 which when repeated is the same. Her baseline BP during earlier visits was 120/80 mmHg. She does not complain of headache/ blurring of vision or epigastric pain. Abdominal exam reveals a term uterus with cephalic presentation and FHR of 140 bpm. Urine albumin is nil. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Gestational hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: page 1780, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: page 1780, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of HELLP syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Retroplacental hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ HELLP Syndrome
  • ➤ HELLP Syndrome
  • ➤ It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm 3 It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension. It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria
  • ➤ It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm 3
  • ➤ It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension.
  • ➤ It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1849, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1849, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A Primigravida presents at 32 weeks with pre-eclampsia. She complains of decreased fetal movements. An umbilical artery Doppler is done which is as shown in the image. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Immediate delivery

questions.text: Which of the following are feature(s) of magnesium toxicity in pregnancy? Loss of deep tendon reflex Decreased respiratory rate Decreased urine output Hypertension Increased heart rate
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. a, b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Features of Magnesium Toxicity:
  • ➤ Features of Magnesium Toxicity:
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute) Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema Cardiac arrest O 2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%) Double vision Slurred speech Nausea-vomiting Muscular weakness
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign
  • ➤ Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
  • ➤ Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema
  • ➤ Cardiac arrest
  • ➤ O 2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%)
  • ➤ Double vision
  • ➤ Slurred speech
  • ➤ Nausea-vomiting
  • ➤ Muscular weakness
  • ➤ **Decreased urine output is not a feature of Mg toxicity. Renal failure can be seen in severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia and as Mg is excreted through the kidneys, decreased renal function can increase the Mg levels in the blood thereby leading to Mg toxicity.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1880, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1880, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 34-year Primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her mother is a diabetic and she is screened for Diabetes at her 8 weeks antenatal visit. What was the most likely screening method used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. HBA1C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective (Summary):
  • ➤ Hemoglobin A1C (HBA1C) is the most likely screening method used for diabetes at the 8-week antenatal visit, especially when there is a family history of diabetes. It provides a longer-term view of blood sugar control.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: An infant was born at 36 weeks of pregnancy with a birthweight 4.5 kg as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gestational Diabetes mellitus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The birth of an infant with a birthweight of 4.5 kg at 36 weeks of pregnancy is suggestive of macrosomia. Macrosomia is commonly associated with maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), which can lead to larger birthweights in babies.
  • ➤ The birth of an infant with a birthweight of 4.5 kg at 36 weeks of pregnancy is suggestive of macrosomia.
  • ➤ Macrosomia is commonly associated with maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), which can lead to larger birthweights in babies.

questions.text: For diagnosis of overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS] level should be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. ≥ 126 mg/dl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To diagnose overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS) level should be ≥ 126 mg/dl (milligrams per decilitre).
  • ➤ To diagnose overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS) level should be ≥ 126 mg/dl (milligrams per decilitre).
  • ➤ It's important to note that the diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes may vary in different guidelines and regions. However, a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dl is a commonly recognized threshold for diagnosing overt gestational diabetes.
  • ➤ It's important to note that the diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes may vary in different guidelines and regions. However, a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dl is a commonly recognized threshold for diagnosing overt gestational diabetes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 34-year Primi who is a known diabetic on insulin presents at 34 weeks pregnancy. On examination, the uterus is 34 weeks and FHR is 140 bpm. Her blood sugar is well controlled. At what period of gestation should her delivery be planned?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 38 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, delivery is planned at 38 weeks. Earlier delivery may be planned if there are poorly controlled sugars or non-reassuring fetal status
  • ➤ In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, delivery is planned at 38 weeks.
  • ➤ Earlier delivery may be planned if there are poorly controlled sugars or non-reassuring fetal status
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1107, Williams Obstetrics, Page no 509, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Dutta
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1107, Williams Obstetrics, Page no 509, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Dutta

questions.text: All are true regarding physiology of pregnancy except?

options.label: B
options.text: Insulin resistance is due to placental hormones

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal insulin can cross the placenta

options.label: D
options.text: The fetus starts secreting insulin at 12 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Maternal insulin can cross the placenta
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Maternal insulin can cross the placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In pregnancy, there is an increase in insulin secretion due to increased insulin resistance, largely driven by placental hormones. However, maternal insulin does not cross the placenta; the fetus produces its own insulin in response to glucose that crosses from the maternal circulation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pre-gestational diabetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus. The most common anomaly associated with pre-gestational diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).
  • ➤ Mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • ➤ The most common anomaly associated with pre-gestational diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Which hypoglycemic drug cannot be used in diabetes in pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pioglitazone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When treating diabetes in pregnancy, insulin is the preferred medication due to its safety profile. Metformin and glyburide can also be used, albeit with some caution and monitoring. Pioglitazone, on the other hand, is not recommended for use during pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and potential fetal risks.
  • ➤ When treating diabetes in pregnancy, insulin is the preferred medication due to its safety profile.
  • ➤ Metformin and glyburide can also be used, albeit with some caution and monitoring.
  • ➤ Pioglitazone, on the other hand, is not recommended for use during pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and potential fetal risks.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 32-years old G3P2L2 visits an antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. She reveals during history that her first baby weighed 4.6 kg, second baby weighed 4.8 kg, and both were delivered by C-section. Neonatal complications of an infant of diabetic mother except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.  Neonatal hyperglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Neonatal complications (Seen because of Pedersen Hypothesis)
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia Respiratory distress syndrome Hyperbilirubinemia Necrotizing enterocolitis Polycythemia Hypocalcemia Hypomagnesemia Cardiomyopathy
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia
  • ➤ Respiratory distress syndrome
  • ➤ Hyperbilirubinemia
  • ➤ Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • ➤ Polycythemia
  • ➤ Hypocalcemia
  • ➤ Hypomagnesemia
  • ➤ Cardiomyopathy
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with mildly elevated liver enzymes and itching over her body. She has no history of liver disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: This is diagnosed by the Swansea criteria. Patients with AFLP usually present in the 3 rd trimester with jaundice, abdominal pain, vomiting. There is altered liver function along with worsening renal and coagulation parameters. Hypoglycemia is typically seen. Option B: HELLP Syndrome: This is a form of severe preeclampsia so a h/o high BP would usually be mentioned. HELLP syndrome is a triad of H emolysis, E levated L iver Enzymes and L ow P latelets. Option D: Acute viral hepatitis: This can be seen in any trimester. There is a history of fever, constitutional symptoms and jaundice. Serum bilirubin is raised and AST and ALT are very highly raised.
  • • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: This is diagnosed by the Swansea criteria. Patients with AFLP usually present in the 3 rd trimester with jaundice, abdominal pain, vomiting. There is altered liver function along with worsening renal and coagulation parameters. Hypoglycemia is typically seen.
  • • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:
  • • Option B: HELLP Syndrome: This is a form of severe preeclampsia so a h/o high BP would usually be mentioned. HELLP syndrome is a triad of H emolysis, E levated L iver Enzymes and L ow P latelets.
  • • Option B: HELLP Syndrome:
  • • H
  • • E
  • • L
  • • L
  • • P
  • • Option D: Acute viral hepatitis: This can be seen in any trimester. There is a history of fever, constitutional symptoms and jaundice. Serum bilirubin is raised and AST and ALT are very highly raised.
  • • Option D: Acute viral hepatitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference- Page no 270, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Acute fatty liver of pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with high fetal and maternal morbidity and mortality

options.label: B
options.text: Commonly occurs in the 2 nd trimester

options.label: C
options.text: It has an association with gestational diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Which is not seen in pregnancy regarding renal changes in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Kidney increases in pregnancy by about 1.5 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than the right side

options.label: C
options.text: An increased GFR leads to lower serum creatinine levels

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than the right side

questions.text: A 30y primigravida presents in labor at 38 weeks. The resident notes that she is HBsAg positive. Which of the following statements regarding immunization of a newborn born to a HBsAg positive mother is true?

options.label: B

questions.text: Obstetric causes of Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) in pregnancy include all except?
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: A 27-year G2P1L1 presents at 33 weeks with itching mainly on the palms of her hands. The itching worsens at night. She gives a similar history in her 1 st pregnancy. On examination, her BP is 130/84 mmHg. There is mild icterus and abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus with fetal heart rate of 140 bpm. Her SGOT is 112 IU/L, SGPT is 124 IU/L and serum bilirubin is 2 mg%. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Monitor BP and plan delivery at 37 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Gestational Diabetes

questions.text: To define preeclampsia, the proteinuria defined is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. ≥ 300 mg/ 24 h

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The diagnosis of preeclampsia involves assessing for the presence of hypertension and significant proteinuria, defined as the excretion of 300 mg or more of protein in a 24-hour urine collection.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 712, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 712, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: All are true regarding gestational hypertension except?

options.label: A
options.text: The diagnosis is made if BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks in the absence of proteinuria

options.label: B
options.text: 10% of eclamptic seizures develop in women with gestational hypertension

options.label: C
options.text: The diagnosis is made only if the blood pressure does not return to normal after 12 weeks postpartum

options.label: D
options.text: It is also known as transient hypertension as the BP returns to normal postpartum

questions.correct_answer: C. The diagnosis is made only if the blood pressure does not return to normal after 12 weeks postpartum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The diagnosis is made only if the blood pressure does not return to normal after 12 weeks postpartum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: Patellar reflexes disappear when the plasma magnesium level reaches:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 10 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Monitoring for magnesium toxicity is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate, especially in obstetric settings for conditions like preeclampsia or eclampsia. The loss of deep tendon reflexes, such as the patellar reflex, is the first clinical sign and usually occurs at plasma magnesium levels around 10 mEq/L.
  • ➤ Monitoring for magnesium toxicity is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate, especially in obstetric settings for conditions like preeclampsia or eclampsia.
  • ➤ The loss of deep tendon reflexes, such as the patellar reflex, is the first clinical sign and usually occurs at plasma magnesium levels around 10 mEq/L.

questions.text: A 25-year-old P2L2 had just delivered following induction for severe preeclampsia. Her BP on the 2 nd postnatal day is 160/100mmHg. Which anti-hypertensive should be avoided in a breastfeeding mother?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Amlodipine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Antihypertensive agents with no known adverse effects on infants receiving breast milk: Mnemonic: ECLAM-N Enalapril Captopril Labetalol Atenolol Metoprolol Nifedipine

questions.text: A 37-year lady with chronic hypertension visits the gynecologist for pre-conceptional counselling. She is currently taking Telmisartan for her hypertension. Which is the correct statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop Telmisartan 3 months prior to conception and re-start it at the 3 rd month of pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol

options.label: D
options.text: Continue Telmisartan and add Labetalol if BP is uncontrolled in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are nor formed and are therefore contra-indicated in pregnancy.
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are nor formed and are therefore contra-indicated in pregnancy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: During a routine antenatal visit, an 24-year G1 at 20 weeks gestational age undergoes a urinalysis. The dipstick done indicates the presence of glycosuria. All other parameters of the urine test are normal. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of sugar detected in the urine?

options.label: B
options.text: The patient has a urine infection

options.label: C
options.text: The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: The patient’s urine sample is contaminated.

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological glycosuria, a normal response to hormonal changes in pregnancy, may lead to the presence of glucose in the urine without underlying diabetes. It is essential to consider other factors, such as diabetes, urinary tract infections, and sample contamination, and perform further tests if necessary to determine the cause of glycosuria.
  • ➤ Physiological glycosuria, a normal response to hormonal changes in pregnancy, may lead to the presence of glucose in the urine without underlying diabetes. It is essential to consider other factors, such as diabetes, urinary tract infections, and sample contamination, and perform further tests if necessary to determine the cause of glycosuria.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Which is NOT seen in gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Malformations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically not associated with congenital malformations GDM can lead to complications such as polyhydramnios, especially if blood sugar levels are uncontrolled during pregnancy. Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM and a previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic baby increases the risk of GDM in subsequent pregnancies.
  • ➤ Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically not associated with congenital malformations
  • ➤ GDM can lead to complications such as polyhydramnios, especially if blood sugar levels are uncontrolled during pregnancy.
  • ➤ Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM and a previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic baby increases the risk of GDM in subsequent pregnancies.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Pederson’s hypothesis states that:

options.label: A
options.text: Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications

options.label: B
options.text: Maternal insulin can cross the placenta resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal hyperglycemia results in an increased incidence of congenital anomalies

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in a lower incidence of respiratory distress syndrome

questions.correct_answer: A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia. This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  • ➤ This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 36-year diabetic woman on insulin is planning conception. She is worried about the risk of fetal congenital anomalies and visits for preconception counseling. Which of the following is the correct statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Caudal regression syndrome is a commonly associated anomaly seen in diabetes

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of anomalies in the fetus is inversely proportional to the level of HBA1c.

options.label: C
options.text: Folic acid in a dose of 5 mg/day started in the preconception period will not reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

options.label: D
options.text: Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

questions.correct_answer: D. Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While higher HbA1c levels are associated with increased risks, the use of certain oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin and glyburide is considered safe during pregnancy. Additionally, folic acid supplementation is important for reducing the risk of neural tube defects.
  • ➤ While higher HbA1c levels are associated with increased risks, the use of certain oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin and glyburide is considered safe during pregnancy.
  • ➤ Additionally, folic acid supplementation is important for reducing the risk of neural tube defects.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents to the OPD at 24 weeks. She is advised to get a Glucose Challenge Test done. All are true regarding the glucose challenge test (GCT) except?

options.label: A
options.text: It is done in the fasting state

options.label: B
options.text: Patients with a positive GCT are subjected to a GTT

options.label: C
options.text: The lower the threshold taken in a GCT, the higher the sensitivity for detection of gestational diabetes mellitus

questions.correct_answer: A. It is done in the fasting state
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. It is done in the fasting state.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Glucose Challenge Test is a non-fasting, initial screening test for gestational diabetes conducted between 24 to 28 weeks of pregnancy. A positive GCT necessitates further testing with a Glucose Tolerance Test. Adjusting the threshold level of the GCT can impact its sensitivity and specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.
  • ➤ The Glucose Challenge Test is a non-fasting, initial screening test for gestational diabetes conducted between 24 to 28 weeks of pregnancy.
  • ➤ A positive GCT necessitates further testing with a Glucose Tolerance Test. Adjusting the threshold level of the GCT can impact its sensitivity and specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 262, DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 262, DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: As per IADPSG recommendations, pre-gestational diabetes is diagnosed in the 1 st antenatal visit by all of the values given below except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. PPBS ≥ 140 mg/dl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In diagnosing pre-gestational diabetes during the first antenatal visit, IADPSG guidelines include criteria such as a fasting blood sugar of ≥ 126 mg/dL, an HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%, or a random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • ➤ In diagnosing pre-gestational diabetes during the first antenatal visit, IADPSG guidelines include criteria such as a fasting blood sugar of ≥ 126 mg/dL, an HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%, or a random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: Target blood glucose levels for women with gestational diabetes on treatment are:

options.label: A
options.text: FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL

options.label: B
options.text: FBS < 90 mg/dl, 1h PP < 145 mg/ dl, 2h < 125 mg/dl

options.label: C
options.text: FBS < 105 mg/dl, 1h PP < 140 mg/dl, 2h PP < 120 mg/dl

options.label: D
options.text: FBS < 95 mg/dl, 1h PP < 120 mg/ dl, 2h PP < 140 mg/dl

questions.correct_answer: A. FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.  FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For the management of gestational diabetes, target blood glucose levels are set to ensure both maternal and fetal well-being. The recommended targets are: fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.
  • ➤ For the management of gestational diabetes, target blood glucose levels are set to ensure both maternal and fetal well-being. The recommended targets are: fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.
  • ➤ fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.
  • ➤ fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL
  • ➤ 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL
  • ➤ 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 264, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 264, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9 th edition

questions.text: All the following precautions are taken in labor in a woman with pre-eclampsia except?

options.label: A
options.text: Cut short the 2 nd stage of labor

options.label: B
options.text: Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder

questions.correct_answer: B. Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Precautions to be taken in labor in women with pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ Restrict IV fluids to avoid pulmonary edema Cut short 2 nd stage of labor using instrumental delivery Avoid methylergometrine at delivery of anterior shoulder Active management of 3 rd stage of labor including Oxytocin 10IU IM
  • ➤ Restrict IV fluids to avoid pulmonary edema
  • ➤ Cut short 2 nd stage of labor using instrumental delivery
  • ➤ Avoid methylergometrine at delivery of anterior shoulder
  • ➤ Active management of 3 rd stage of labor including Oxytocin 10IU IM
  • ➤ Ref: page no 440, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition
  • ➤ Ref: page no 440, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1 st edition

questions.text: All of the following indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia in a pregnant female of chronic hypertension except:

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

questions.text: Elective cesarean delivery is indicated in a diabetic woman if the estimated fetal weight is
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. > 4500g

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ As per ACOG, for diabetic pregnant women, an elective cesarean delivery is recommended if the estimated fetal weight exceeds 4.5 kg. This is in contrast to non-diabetic women, where the threshold for an elective cesarean is set at an estimated fetal weight of more than 5 kg. The lower threshold for diabetic women is due to the increased risk of macrosomia and related birth complications, including shoulder dystocia.
  • ➤ As per ACOG, for diabetic pregnant women, an elective cesarean delivery is recommended if the estimated fetal weight exceeds 4.5 kg.
  • ➤ This is in contrast to non-diabetic women, where the threshold for an elective cesarean is set at an estimated fetal weight of more than 5 kg.
  • ➤ The lower threshold for diabetic women is due to the increased risk of macrosomia and related birth complications, including shoulder dystocia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 25 th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with primary genital herpes infection. What is the most appropriate management regarding delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Elective cesarean delivery regardless of the presence of lesions at the time of labor

options.label: B
options.text: Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal delivery with administration of antiviral prophylaxis

options.label: D
options.text: Induction of labor at 37 weeks to reduce the risk of neonatal infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor

Explanation:

  • • .

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If there is active genital herpes at term, cesarean section has to be done
  • ➤ If there is active genital herpes at term, cesarean section has to be done

  • ➤ Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5 th edition

questions.text: A multiparous patient who did not attend any antenatal visit and came to causality with complaint of bleeding. On examination uterine tone was increased with BP>144/92 mmHg. Which of the following tests supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia?

options.label: D
options.text: Total protein of 252mg in a 24-hour urine collection

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Creatinine levels 1.24mg/dl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Preeclampsia Definitions
  • ➤ Preeclampsia
  • ➤ Preeclampsia
  • ➤ Hypertension and proteinuria or In absence of proteinuria, new-onset hypertension with the new onset of any of the following Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Impaired liver function: Elevated blood concentrations of liver transaminases to twice normal concentration Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Hypertension and proteinuria or
  • ➤ or
  • ➤ In absence of proteinuria, new-onset hypertension with the new onset of any of the following Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Impaired liver function: Elevated blood concentrations of liver transaminases to twice normal concentration Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Impaired liver function: Elevated blood concentrations of liver transaminases to twice normal concentration Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L
  • ➤ Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
  • ➤ Impaired liver function: Elevated blood concentrations of liver transaminases to twice normal concentration
  • ➤ Pulmonary edema
  • ➤ Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ or
  • ➤ Preeclampsia with severe features
  • ➤ Preeclampsia with severe features
  • ➤ Preeclampsia diagnosis, above, with any of the following Severe hypertension On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy) Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Impaired liver function (without an alternative diagnosis): Elevated liver transaminases greater than twice upper limit of normal or severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not responsive to medications Progressive renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Preeclampsia diagnosis, above, with any of the following Severe hypertension On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy) Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Impaired liver function (without an alternative diagnosis): Elevated liver transaminases greater than twice upper limit of normal or severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not responsive to medications Progressive renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Severe hypertension On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy) Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L Impaired liver function (without an alternative diagnosis): Elevated liver transaminases greater than twice upper limit of normal or severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not responsive to medications Progressive renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease Pulmonary edema Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ Severe hypertension On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy)
  • ➤ On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy)
  • ➤ On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy)
  • ➤ Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 10 9 /L
  • ➤ Impaired liver function (without an alternative diagnosis): Elevated liver transaminases greater than twice upper limit of normal or severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not responsive to medications
  • ➤ or
  • ➤ or
  • ➤ Progressive renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
  • ➤ Pulmonary edema
  • ➤ Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms
  • ➤ or
  • ➤ Note: The following are not diagnostic criteria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia or preeclampsia with severe features
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Clinically evident edema Rapid weight gain Massive proteinuria Does not qualify as a ‘severe feature’ Fetal growth restriction Expectant management ‘may be reasonable’ if mother and fetus appear stable and no other clinical indication is present that would indicate the need for early delivery ACOG states that while it is important to monitor fetal status, FGR in the setting of all other fetal assessment being within normal limits (e.g., AFV, Doppler) Uric acid Hyperuricemia in hypertensive pregnancy is not a diagnostic marker, but is an important finding as a risk factor for adverse maternal and fetal outcomes Small for gestational age (SGA) infant Prematurity Risk for adverse maternal outcomes if include patients with preeclampsia and risks increase with increasing concentration of uric acid May be warranted in the setting of ‘diagnostic dilemmas’ such as diagnosing superimposed preeclampsia in the setting of chronic hypertension

questions.text: The highest risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome is?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. 12-20 weeks

questions.text: A 25 y woman is planning to conceive. She is unsure of her childhood vaccination status. Which of the following vaccines should she receive before conceiving?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Rubella

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1L1 teacher presents at 22 weeks with fever and rash since 2 days. She gives history of contact with a child in her class who had chicken pox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration

questions.text: Which of the following infections can cause fetal hydrops?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Parvovirus

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester presents with fever, rash, and arthralgia. She recently returned from a trip to a region where Zika virus is endemic. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Order Zika virus testing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zika virus in pregnancy
  • ➤ Zika virus in pregnancy
  • ➤ This RNA flavivirus is the first major mosquito-borne teratogen recognized Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito bite, but sexual transmission is possible. Maternal-Fetal Infection: Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults. It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days. The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic. In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures Diagnosis and Management. Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months. For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended. For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection. Currently, no specific treatment or vaccine is available for Zika infection, although several vaccines are in development
  • ➤ This RNA flavivirus is the first major mosquito-borne teratogen recognized
  • ➤ Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito bite, but sexual transmission is possible.
  • ➤ Maternal-Fetal Infection: Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults. It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days. The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic. In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures
  • ➤ Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults. It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days. The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic. In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures
  • ➤ Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults.
  • ➤ It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days.
  • ➤ The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic.
  • ➤ In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures
  • ➤ Diagnosis and Management. Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months. For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended. For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection.
  • ➤ Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months. For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended. For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection.
  • ➤ Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission
  • ➤ Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months.
  • ➤ For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended.
  • ➤ For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection.
  • ➤ Currently, no specific treatment or vaccine is available for Zika infection, although several vaccines are in development
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26 th edition pg 3107
